On Mon, Jul 23, 2018 at 3:02 AM, nimroha ***@***.***> wrote:
 @vsai121 <https://github.com/vsai121> I solved it
 in MultiRNN zero_state is a tuple of the states of each layer. so:

 new_state = tuple([cells.zero_state(batch_size, tf.float32)[i].clone(cell_state=initial_state[i])
 for i in range(num_layers)])

body:
We should consider a helper function that uses nest.map_structure to do
this for you.

On Mon, Jul 23, 2018 at 3:02 AM, nimroha <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @vsai121 <https://github.com/vsai121> I solved it
> in MultiRNN zero_state is a tuple of the states of each layer. so:
>
> new_state = tuple([cells.zero_state(batch_size, tf.float32)[i].clone(cell_state=initial_state[i])
> for i in range(num_layers)])
>
